questions.question_text: Which protocol is used in the Cisco ACI fabric for automatic discovery?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Cisco ACI fabric for automatic discovery uses only LLDP and DHCP protocol but DHCP is not int the options so LLDP is correct

Selected Answer: D
In Cisco ACI, when a service graph is deployed under one tenant (e.g., Operations) and needs to be referenced by another tenant (e.g., Management), the Layer 4-Layer 7 (L4-L7) device export action is used. This allows the firewall or other L4-L7 devices defined in the service graph to be shared across tenants. By exporting the L4-L7 device, the configuration enables the Management tenant to reference and use the firewall deployed in the Operations tenant.

Selected Answer: D
L4-L7 device can’t be referenced from other tenants. If you want to share an L4-L7 device with other tenants, you need to export the L4-L7 device to other tenants. It will appear as an imported device in the other tenants

questions.question_text: A Cisco ACI fabric is integrated with a Cisco ASA firewall using a service graph under the tenant called Operations. The fabric must permit the firewall used on tenant Operations to be referenced by the tenant called Management. Which export action must be used to accomplish this goal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Cisco ACI does not run Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) within the fabric itself, as it operates as a routed fabric with a loop-free topology by design. However, when connecting ACI to external devices like Cisco Nexus 9000 switches, it is crucial to ensure a loop-free topology at the Layer 2 boundary.

Selected Answer: D
MCP for loop-free topology

choices.D: Activate MCP on ports between the leaf and Nexus 9000 Series Switches.
choices.A: Enable STP on ports between the leaf and spine.
choices.B: Set BPDU Guard on ports between the leaf and Nexus 9000 Series Switches.
choices.C: Enable Cisco Discovery Protocol on ports between the leaf and spine.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer connects a Cisco ACI fabric to two different Cisco Nexus 9000 Series Switches. The fabric must be configured to ensure a loop-free topology and N9K1 must be configured as the root bridge for VLAN 10. Which action meets these requirements?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
In OSPF, mismatched MTU settings between two devices can prevent the OSPF adjacency from forming. By default, Cisco Nexus 9000 switches in NX-OS mode perform an MTU check during the OSPF adjacency negotiation process. If the MTU values on the interfaces of BLeaf1 and Core1 do not match, the adjacency will fail to establish.
To resolve this issue, you need to ensure that both devices have matching MTU settings. Changing the MTU on Core1 to match BLeaf1 will allow the OSPF adjacency to form successfully. This is a common troubleshooting step when dealing with OSPF adjacency issues caused by MTU mismatches.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

choices.A: Set and Auth Key on Core1.

questions.question_text:
An engineer configures an L3Out between BLeaf1 and Core1. A Cisco Nexus 9000 Series Switch runs in NX-OS mode, and the two devices must peer using OSPF. The devices in the network are configured as follows:

• BLeaf1 has been configured with the IP address 10.1.0.2/31 and the router ID 0.0.0.2.
• Core1 has been configured with the IP address 10.1.0.3/31 and the router ID 0.0.0.1.
• On Cisco ACI, the engineer has enabled OSPF using the default OSPF settings.
• The engineer has configured OSPF on the NX-OS switch using the ip router ospf ACI_peering area 1 command.

Which action brings up the OSPF adjacency?

choices.A: Enable a BGP peer prefix policy set to Always.
choices.D: Implement an export route map matching 0.0.0.0/0.
choices.B: Configure a static default route on the ACI node profiles with next-hop null.
choices.C: Create a Default Route Leak Policy on the L3Out.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
For external connections to the fabric that only require a default route, there is support for originating a default route for OSPF, EIGRP, and BGP L3Out connections. If a default route is received from an external peer, this route can be redistributed out to another peer following the transit export route control as described earlier in this article.

A default route can also be advertised out using a Default Route Leak policy. This policy supports advertising a default route if it is present in the routing table or it always supports advertising a default route. The Default Route Leak policy is configured in the L3Out connection. https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/aci/apic/sw/2-x/L3_config/b_Cisco_APIC_Layer_3_Configuration_Guide/b_Cisco_APIC_Layer_3_Configuration_Guide_chapter_010100.html

Selected Answer: C
There are two methods to advertise a default route (0.0.0.0/0) from BGP L3Out to the outside.
1. Transit Routing
2. Default Route Leak Policy
